epigraph.p: Translator 's Note The translation of dramatic dialogue is attended with special difficulties , and these are peculiarly marked in translating from German into English . The German sentence carries more ballast than English readers are accustomed to , and while in translating narrative one may , by means of subordinate clauses , follow the conformation of the original , it is hard to do so in rendering conversation , and virtually impossible when the conversation is meant to be spoken on the stage . To English and American spectators the long German speeches are a severe strain on the attention , and even in a translation intended only for the “ closet ” a too faithful adherence to German construction is not the best way of doing justice to the original . Herr Sudermann 's dialogue is more concise than that of many other German dramatists ; yet in translation his sentences and speeches need to be divided and recast : to preserve the spirit , the letter must be modified . This is true not only of the construction of his dialogue but also of his forms of expression . Wherever it has been possible , his analogies , his allusions , his “ tours de phrase , ” have been scrupulously followed ; but where they seemed to obscure his meaning to English readers some adaptation has been necessary . Apart from these trifling changes , the original has been closely followed ; and such modifications as have been made were suggested solely by the wish to reproduce Herr Sudermann 's meaning more closely than a literal translation would have allowed .

set.p: The scene is laid in Berlin — the first three and the fifth acts at the house of Count Kellinghausen ; the fourth act at Baron Richard Voelkerlingk 's .

stage.stage: A drawing-room in the Empire style in Count Kellinghausen 's house . In the centre of back wall a wide opening between two columns , partly closed by an old Gobelins tapestry . On the right a sofa , table and chairs . On the left , in front of the fireplace , several low seats . sp.p: What do you hear from Kellinghausen ? He is still at Lengenfeld , I hear .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: I have just had a letter . Now that the elections are over he means to take a day 's shooting , and then he is coming home — free from his party-duties for the first time in years !

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: And what does the Egeria of the party say to such a state of things ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Do you mean me , your Excellency ?

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: I mean the woman at whose delightful dinner-table the fate of more than one important bill has been decided . Now that Kellinghausen has retired into private life , do you mean to keep up the little political dinners we 've always been so much afraid of ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: I hope so , your Excellency . And if you care to beard the lion in his den , I shall be charmed to send you an invitation . You have n't dined with us in an age . I 've always fancied that the estrangement between your brother and yourself might be the cause of our seeing so little of you .

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: My dear Countess , those eyes of yours see through everything ; and I read in them all the answers I might make to that question . Ah , well — Richard had the good luck , the unspeakable good luck , to win your friendship , and under your influence , to develop into the man he is !

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: I know how to listen when clever men are talking . That is the secret of what you call my influence .

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: You think so ?— Well — there was Richard , dabbling in poetry and politics , in archaeology and explorations , like the typical noble amateur . He had a fortune from his mother , while I was poor . But in one respect I was richer than he ; for he married a fool who dragged him down to the level of her own silly snobbishness . But then you came — and lifted him up again . Then all his dormant powers awoke — he discovered his gift as a speaker , he became the mouthpiece of the party , he got into the Reichstag , and ——

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: And dropped out again .

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: Exactly . And the estrangement between us dates from that time . It was reported that government had left him in the lurch , and I was thought to be more or less responsible .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: At all events , his career was cut short . And he failed again at the next election .

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: And now your friendship has helped him to success .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: My husband 's friendship , you mean .

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: In my loveless household I know too little of the power of woman to pronounce definitely on that point .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: You do well to suspend your judgment .

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: Ah , now you are displeased with me . I am sorry . I might be of use to you .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: If you wish to be of use to me you can do so by becoming your brother 's friend . It was to ask you this that I sent for you .

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: Countess , I wonder at your faith in human nature !

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Human nature has never deceived me .

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: One would adore you for saying that if one had n't so many other reasons for doing so ! BeatalaughingPretty speeches at our age ?

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: You may talk of my age , but not of yours .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Look at the grey hair — here , on my temples ; and my medicine-bottles over there . I never stir without them now .

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: I have been distressed to hear of your illness .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Yes , my heart bothers me — an old story . My heart is tired — and I — I 'm not . And when I drive it too hard it grows a little restive now and then . sp.p: How do you do , young lady ? Dear me dear me what have you been growing into ?

sp.speaker: Ellen
sp.p: Into life , your Excellency !

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: Ha — very good — very neat . So many people just grow past it .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: And how was the skating , dear ?

sp.speaker: Ellen

sp.p: What a little wonder you 've made of her !

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: She is developing , is n't she ?

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: I confess , Countess , that even if Kellinghausen looked upon his politics merely as a branch of sport , I do n't quite understand his sacrificing his career to my brother .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: My husband is very easy-going . He has no ambition . They had bothered him dreadfully at their committee-meetings about things he did n't understand — at least he said he did n't . The truth is , it probably bored him .

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: But how about his fanatical devotion to the party ? If we are all monomaniacs on that subject , he is certainly the worst . sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: I need n't tell you , Herr von Brachtmann , how pleasant it is to hear my brother praised . sp.speaker: Beata

sp.speaker: Prince

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: Really , Prince — pardon me — but since , by birth and political affiliations , you are a supporter of existing institutions , would it not be well to speak of them less flippantly ?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Why , my dear Baron ?— Countess , shall I show you the attitude of the modern state toward its citizens ? There 's the situation in a nutshell . It 's a matter of taste whether one respects such an institution or not .

sp.speaker: Brachtmann

sp.p: No , she is just the same as usual . But at night — oh , Norbert , she 's never in bed . All night she wanders , wanders . When I hear her coming , I lie quite still . If she knew I was awake she might not come any more . She never touches me , but just bends over and strokes my pillow , oh , so softly ! And she breathes so hard , as if it hurt her — and then gradually she grows quiet again . When you see her in the daytime , so gay and dear and busy , so full of other people 's pleasures , you 'd never guess the misery she endures . Oh , Norbert , you do love her , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: Norbert

sp.speaker: Ellen

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: Perhaps not , but I can n't help feeling it . And why should n't I , after all ? When I was a boy my father was everything to me — after that he was always travelling , and I was left to my own devices . There are so many things that puzzle a chap when there 's no one to talk them over with . It 's different with girls , I suppose . At first I used to go to my mother : she 's always found life simple enough . Visits , and parties , and church — she looks upon church-going as another kind of visiting — well , do you know what she said to me ? “ In the first place , my dear boy , your trousers are shocking . What you need is a good tailor . Then you ought to take up lawn tennis — and after that , we 'll see . ” Well , that did n't help me much . And then your mother took pity on me . Again and again she 's let me sit up half the night , talking things over with her .

sp.speaker: Ellen
sp.p: And now you and she have got something to say to each other again . What is it , Norbert ? Do tell me ! Why can n't I help you as well as mother ?

sp.speaker: Norbert

sp.speaker: Ellen

sp.speaker: Norbert

lg.l: Listen , dear . I made an awful ass of myself that day . Do you know what
I did ? I called on your father to ask his permission to marry you .

sp.speaker: Ellen
sp.p: And you never told me ?

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: Luckily your father was out — and as for your mother — well , she simply laughed at me !

sp.speaker: Ellen
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: Oh , you know how your mother laughs at one . It does n't hurt . “ Dear boy , ” she said , in the kindest way , “ it 's too soon to talk of such things to Ellen . You must give her time to grow up . ” And I gave her my word I would ; and you see I 've kept it .

lg.stage: who has been watching them closely
lg.l: By the way , Norbert — what about that promise you made me ?

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: I 've kept it , Aunt Beata .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Then you want to talk to me about something else ?

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: Yes . The storm-signals are up . My college club has turned on me : one , two , three , and out you go !

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Not in disgrace ?

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: I 'm not so sure . I got an official letter yesterday from the committee , asking me if I was the author of a pamphlet called “ The Ordeal . ”

sp.p: Why did you write it under an assumed name ?

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: Only on my father 's account .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: If you disguised yourself at all , you ought to have done so more thoroughly .

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: Why , Aunt Beata ! Have n't you often told me that every reformer must have the courage of his convictions ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Yes ; but I 've no sympathy with unnecessary martyrdom . Keep a cool head , dear boy , and do n't be drawn into controversy just yet . Have n't I often told you that this college duelling you rail against is only a preparation for the real battle of life — the battle of ideas and beliefs ? You 'll come to that later — ask your father how it is !

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: Oh , father — of course he 's only interested in big things .

sp.speaker: Beata

sp.speaker: Norbert

sp.speaker: Norbert

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: There 's no use in trying to deceive you . Have you just come from your own house ?

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Well ? Telegrams ?

lg.l: None for the last two hours . Well , Norbert , you here , as usual ?
So you have the younger generation on your hands too ?
So much the better , since the older shows itself so seldom nowadays .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Ah , well ——

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Good-bye , Norbert dear . Norbertkissing Beata 's handGood-bye , father .Richard nods to him . Norbert goes out .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Will you dine with me to-day , Richard ?Richard shakes his head .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Just we two ?

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: I can n't : my wife has a dinner : an ambassador and his wife , two lights of the Church , and others of the same feather . I must show myself on such occasions , to keep up appearances .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: I 'm sorry . I should have liked to have you with me — to-day . How do you stand the suspense ? Perhaps I do n't show it — but I 'm in a fever .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: It 's telling on me too . The fact is , any poor devil of a mountebank is a king compared to one of us . He does his trick and gets his pay .— Oh , this last fortnight ! If you 'd seen me driven about from village to village like a travelling quack ! Freedom and hot words , free beer and hot sausages ! And , to cap the climax , a fellow who used to be my private secretary leading the campaign against me ! Bah — it was horrible . As for Michael , with his Olympian calm , he saw only the humorous side of it .Laughing .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: I wonder he let you leave before the election .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: He thought I ought not to make myself too cheap . I quite agreed with him , and took myself off . Hang the democracy !

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: If only the noblemen who want to rule could get on without it !

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: They could , if the spirit of the age had n't turned them into demagogues .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Did Holtzmann do as well as you expected ?

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Admirably . But he 's been going about with such a long face lately that he 's rather got on my nerves .— I heard you had told him to come back when the returns are in — may I wait for him here ?— When one thinks that something will come in at that door presently — something dressed like Holtzmann , looking like Holtzmann — and that that something will be Fate — nothing more or less than Fate !

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: And if he comes in and says — or rather , if he does n't say anything ? Remember , Richard , even if that happens , you 've got to go on living !

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Of course . Why not ? It 's all in the day 's work . An Indian penitent was once asked : “ Why do you go on living ? ” And his answer was : “ Because I am dead . ” — Oh , I do n't mean to be ungrateful . As long as I have you , dear — as long as you are here to live my life with me , to give it colour and meaning and purpose — let come what may , nothing else matters .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Do n't say that — do n't ——

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Am I exaggerating ? Why , ever since we — How long ago is it that we met for the first time , in the wood at Tarasp ? Fifteen years ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: It seems like yesterday .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: You passed between the dark pine-trunks like an apparition . You wore a pink dress and had Ellen by the hand .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: She was tired and had begun to cry .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: I saw that she wanted to be carried .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: And I was just recovering from an illness , and was too weak to lift her . You raised your hat — no , it was the white cap you wore ——

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Do you remember that ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Good heavens , what was I then , and what have you made of me ? My own — let me call you that just once , Richard , as I used to do — just once , on this great day — my own !Richard looks nervously toward the door .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: There is no one coming .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Let you !

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: What a quiet happy little woman I was ! That “ happy ” is not meant as a reproach , dearest ! I have a boundless capacity for happiness , and it kept me company even in the loneliness of my early married life — for in those days Michael did n't take much notice of me . It was you who showed him that I was worth noticing . And so you built up my new life — a hard life to carry , at times , a life bowed under its own wealth as the vine is bowed under its fruit — but how it has grown under your hand , dearest , how it has spread and strengthened !— Now you 're laughing at me , Richard .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Beata — no one knows as you do how I have blundered and struggled . What are you trying to do ? Do you want to give me more faith in myself , or do you really think I 've done all that for you ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: I know every line in your forehead , I watch every look in your eye , I read every thought in your soul — there are some I could wish away , for they only make you miserable — but no one knows as I do what you are , and what you have been to me !

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: When will Michael be here ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: How suddenly you ask that ! You are tormenting yourself again . Dear — dearest — do n't look like that ! Why , it never really happened — it 's been dead and buried for years — dead and buried , every trace of it . No one knows what we were to each other , no one even dreams it . And we 're old people now — you and I . Only think , I shall soon be forty ! Who is going to ask two old mummies what follies they committed in the year one ?

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: You are pretending not to care , Beata . Do n't do that !

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Do n't weigh every word I say — just look into my wicked heart . Your conscience has nothing to do with that ! And if you 're fond of Michael — if we 're both fond of him — and why should n't we both be fond of him — that dear , good , cheery Michael of ours ?— why , that need n't make you probe the depths of your soul for fresh wickedness . I tell you we 've paid for everything , even to the uttermost farthing !

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Do you think so ? It seems to me that when a man and a woman have found everything in each other , as we have , when they have been to each other the strength and the meaning and the object of life — when they 've resolved to die fighting back to back , together to the last , as you used to say it seems to me that in such a case there is n't much room for expiation . If Purgatory is like that it must be fairly habitable .Beata laughs .Ah , now you are flippant .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Be thankful that one of us is , dear !

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: I remember when I lost my seat , six years ago — it was a hard knock , I can tell you — everything went under at once — well , I said to myself : This is my punishment . And the idea never left me . While I was wandering about the world , or vegetating down in the country , I actually used to get a kind of comfort out of it . And now ? Do you know , I sometimes fancy you would n't be altogether sorry if I lost my election again . BeatalaughinglyReally ? Do you think that ?

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: In fact I 'm not at all sure you hold with the party any longer .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: What — I , its Egeria ? An elderly party-nymph gone wrong ? What a shocking idea !

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: I 'm sure of one thing you enjoy looking over our heads .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Do n't say our heads — do n't include yourself with the rest . You think of your duty ; they think of their rights . You use the masses in order to serve them . The others think only of power .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Oh , as to that — we all want power .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Yes : the question is , for whose benefit ?— Ah , well , I see I shall have to tell you — you ought to know — the sooner the better , I suppose !

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Tell me what ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Dear — did you really think it was Michael 's fondest wish to resign his seat in Parliament , and live only for his horses ?

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: I 've heard him say so often enough .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: And so you leaped into the breach — in the interests of the party ? RichardhesitatingAnd because —suddenlyBeata — there 's been some deception ?Beata nods .Some one has been working against me ——?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Or for you — as you please .— Sit down beside me , dear ; give me both your hands — so ! And now listen . I could n't bear to see your disappointment — your suffering — I suffered with you too intensely ! And so — do n't look so startled , or I shall lose heart and be afraid to go on .— How shall I tell you ?— It 's taken me a year a whole year 's work . By degrees I persuaded him that he was unsuited to Parliamentary life — gradually I turned him against the pottering routine-work which is the only thing he can do — little by little I made him see what a boon it would be for the country and the party if he would only let you take his place . Till at last he did —— Richardrising

sp.speaker: Ah ——
sp.p: Beata . Can you say now that I did n't want you elected ?Richard is silent .I should never have told you this if I had n't known that his pride in his heroic feat would make him betray himself sooner or later .A pause .After all , think how little he 's given up ! To him it was only a — pastime — to you it is life . I had no choice , had I ? You do see that , do n't you ?A pause .Richard , I may be a very wicked woman , but at least I deserve one look from you !

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Beata ! Beata ! What can I say ? What can I say ? You know how I 've always tried to keep our feeling for each other within the bounds — the bounds of — You know how it was twelve years ago — when I found myself gradually slipping into intimacy with him , I came to you and said : “ Either this thing ends here , or I tell him everything . I wo n't take his hand and play the sneak . If I do , we shall lose our respect for each other as well as our self-respect . ” And then we hit on this friendship as a way out of it — a way of not losing each other altogether . It was n't a very honourable solution — but this — this new sacrifice — if I accept this — God ! If Holtzmann were to come in now and tell me the other man has won , what a load he would take off my mind !

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Richard — how can you ?

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Think of it : To-morrow I shall have to make that speech . My position , my convictions , compel me to appear as the spokesman of the highest ideals — and all the while I shall owe my seat to the friend whose holiest ties I have trampled on ——

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: And if they were not the holiest ——? Richardstartled

sp.speaker: Beata !
sp.p: Beata . Do n't turn from me . I 've loved you so long ! Richardclasps her handsOne thing more . Listen to me . You played too reckless a game . Such things are avenged . No one knows what happened in the past . Twelve years have covered it ; but it 's ill disturbing the dead . Such things are avenged . Remember that .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Well — and what of it ?

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: What of it ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: I should n't care — except for Norbert and Ellen . For I mean them to have all the happiness we have missed . Nothing must ever come between — Hush ! That is Holtzmann 's voice .She presses her left hand to her heart .Quite steady .She holds out her right hand to Richard .Feel my pulse it 's perfectly steady .

lg.l: We have a majority of twenty votes , Baron . Here are the final returns .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Official ?

sp.speaker: Holtzmann
sp.p: Virtually . As your co-worker , Baron , allow me to offer my congratulations .Richard turns away without speaking .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: You see how overcome he is , dear Herr Holtzmann . Thank you with all my heart .Gives him her hand .Holtzmannturning to leave the roomGood-afternoon , Countess .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Holtzmann !Holtzmann pauses .You 've fought a good fight .

sp.speaker: Holtzmann
sp.p: Oh , as to that ——

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Thank you .Shakes his hand .

sp.speaker: Holtzmann
sp.p: Do n't mention it . I did my duty , that 's all .Bows and goes out .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Richard ! Is n't the struggle over yet ?

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Beata — you have made me believe — in spite of myself — that — even now — I may be of use to the cause . I shall stick to my work , and try not to think .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: It may not be as hard as you imagine .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Perhaps not . But when the blow falls — if it falls ——

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: We 'll laugh ——

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: And meanwhile ——

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: We 'll live !They clasp each other 's hands .

div.head: ACT II

sp.speaker: ACT II
sp.p: The same scenery as in the first act . The drawing-room is brightly lit , the curtain in the opening at back of stage drawn back , showing two other apartments , also brilliantly lit . In the nearest one a group of gentlemen are at the billiard-table . In the third room the rest of the guests have just left the table . For some minutes Beata is seen among them . Brachtmann , Prince Usingen and von Berkelwitz-Gruenhof are just coming out of the billiard-room , talking together .

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: Coming forward with Usingen .Prince , I want a word with you later — an important matter .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: And I want a word with you .

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: On the same subject , probably .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Perhaps . von Berkelwitzlooking about himDeuced fine — magnificent ! You 've got to come up to town to see this kind of thing .

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: How is it we never see you in the Reichstag nowadays , my dear fellow ?

sp.speaker: von Berkelwitz
sp.p: What 's a man to do ? I 'm a country squire — I 've got to work — and besides I 'm too poor to live in town . A man has got to make a show here — keep up appearances — I — hang it , that champagne 's gone to my head — what was I going to say ? Oh , yes : well , you see , I 've got four boys growing up ; one is in the Rathenow Hussars — crack regiment , you know — I always look out for that sort of thing — but costs like the devil ! The second is with the Pacific squadron on board the Princess William . He does n't cost as much except when he 's ashore . The third is to study forestry , and just now he 's with his rifle-corps . The fourth is at college — Bonn — belongs to all the most expensive clubs — but smart , deuced smart ! That 's the chief thing . I expect all four to make their living out of the state , but meanwhile they 're a confounded expense to me . You 've no idea what it costs to keep Oscar alone in white gloves ! Princeto BrachtmannAnd these are the sources of German statesmanship !

sp.speaker: von Berkelwitz
sp.p: What did you say , Prince ?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Nothing , nothing .

sp.speaker: von Berkelwitz
sp.p: Not that we can n't give you as good a dinner as you 'll get here . But as to keeping up a countryseat and a town house and a shooting-box and a racing-stable — why , it 's out of the question . I 've had to mortgage my place — and the men 's wages — coming round every Saturday ! well — well — I tell my boys — rich marriages — that 's the cure . And they ought to , by gad ! Good-looking fellows , you understand . What the deuce are we Prussian noblemen for , if the state does n't provide for us ? Just answer me that ! Princewho has been studying the picturesYou ought to ask the Socialists that , Herr von Berkelwitz — ask it in the Reichstag , you know . It would be rather effective .Turns back to the pictures .A capital Sustermans . BrachtmannsmilingAfter all , we 're all looking out for ourselves .

sp.speaker: von Berkelwitz
sp.p: And how have we succeeded ? What have we landed proprietors accomplished ? Oh , we can all talk loud enough ; but when it comes to action , there we stand with our hands in our pockets .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Who is turning over photograph-albums on the table .Other people 's pockets . BrachtmannlaughingPrince — Prince !

sp.speaker: von Berkelwitz
sp.p: In a low tone , to Brachtmann .I say , is that fellow making fun of us ?

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: He 's ten times more of a Conservative than either of us .

sp.speaker: von Berkelwitz
sp.p: He talks like a Radical . Princein a startled tone

sp.speaker: Oh , the devil !
sp.p: Brachtmann . What 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Is n't this the Countess 's writing-table ?

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Come here a moment , will you , and just glance discreetly over these papers . Do you notice anything ?Brachtmann shrugs his shoulders .I mean among the newspapers . Brachtmannin a low voice , much agitatedThe devil !— That was what I wanted to speak to you about .He points to one of the papers .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Ah — they 've sent you one too ?

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: In the same wrapper , addressed in the same hand . An hour ago , just as I left the house . I suppose they have n't had time to look at the last post here .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Taking up the paper and looking at the wrapper .Do you know , I 've half a mind ——

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: No , no , Prince — can n't be done .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: I know it can n't , my dear Baron . That 's the very reason .— Do n't our political opponents say that property is theft ? Why not reverse the axiom , and ——

sp.speaker: von Berkelwitz
sp.p: What the deuce ——?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Why , instead of putting our hands into other people 's pockets , we might put other people 's property into ours .

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: Prince , we all know your way ——

sp.speaker: von Berkelwitz
sp.p: If your Highness has made yourself sufficiently witty at our expense , perhaps you 'll explain what this is ?Pointing to the paper .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: This , my dear Herr von Berkelwitz , is a copy of the “ Lengenfeld News , ” the Socialist organ ——

sp.speaker: von Berkelwitz
sp.p: Faugh ! How can you touch it ?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Well , it touches us , and rather nearly , as you 'll see .

sp.speaker: von Berkelwitz
sp.p: Why , what 's up ?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Taking a newspaper out of his pocket .Look here ——

sp.speaker: von Berkelwitz
sp.p: That 's the same as the other ?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Precisely . I brought it with me on your account . You will find in it an interesting report of a meeting of Socialist electors . Do me the favour to read the passage which they have thoughtfully marked for our benefit . von Berkelwitzreading“ It is seldom that the honourable gentlemen of the Right , the self-constituted guardians of public morality , give us an opportunity to see what goes on behind the scenes , in the gilded saloons to which the man in the street may not presume to penetrate ” — confound their insolence !— “ it is not often that we get a hint of what goes on behind their silken bed-curtains ” — h 'm , I wish they could see what I sleep on !

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Go on . von Berkelwitzreading“ But now and then a happy accident yields us an edifying glimpse of their private histories . And , if I might venture to speak openly , I could give you such a glimpse into the private life of the honourable member from Lengenfeld , and into his relations with the friend whose seat in the Reichstag he has taken — the confiding friend who , instead of keeping watch in his own house , has been travelling from place to place , canvassing for the honourable member .Laughter . Prolonged cheering ." Lengenfeld ? Lengen — why , that is Voelkerlingk 's district .Brachtmann nods affirmatively .

sp.speaker: von Berkelwitz
sp.p: And the friend — the friend who ——?He breaks off , and points vaguely to the room . Brachtmann nods again .The deuce !

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: On account of the party I suppose we shall have to take some notice of this .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Kellinghausen evidently does n't know of it yet . But Voelkerlingk does . I watched him .

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: The Countess is not well . Who is the proper person to take that paper away before she sees it ? PrincesmilingWell , frankly , I should say Voelkerlingk ——

sp.speaker: von Berkelwitz
sp.p: Gentlemen , I 'm only a plain country squire , but I should like to suggest that the morals of our hostess are hardly a subject for discussion .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Morals ? Morals ? What do morals signify ? They were only invented for the preservation of the race .

sp.speaker: von Berkelwitz
sp.p: That 's over my head , your Highness .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: It 's simple enough . Mankind is bound to go on reproducing itself — that 's its fundamental instinct . Morality was invented to keep the strain pure . If it ceases to accomplish that purpose , it had better abdicate in favour of immorality . That 's all .

sp.speaker: von Berkelwitz
sp.p: I 'll be hanged if I understand a single word .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: We all know the old families would n't have survived till now if the stock had n't been renewed — surreptitiously , so to speak — by ——

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: Really , Prince — really ——

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: My dear Brachtmann , it 's all very well for you to look shocked . Your family has n't had to resort to such expedients : your patent of nobility is n't more than two hundred years old . But my people have been misbehaving since the time of Lewis the Pious . Look at the result — look at me . Jaw prognathous — frontal bone asymmetrical — ears abnormal — all the symptoms of a decaying race . Thanks to several centuries of inbreeding , I must go through life a degenerate , and I assure you I have n't any talent for it . If only I could marry a healthy dairy-maid ! Under such circumstances , do you wonder one loses one 's respect for morality ? What if two people in this house have followed the dictates of their temperament ?

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: Prince , von Berkelwitz is right . As long as we 're in the house ourselves , we 'll postpone any discussion of its inmates .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: As you please .Richard Voelkerlingk is seen approaching . The Prince glances toward him .Which wo n't prevent my feeling the sincerest sympathy for our friend there . His phenomenal self-possession is enough to confirm my suspicions .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: I 've been looking for you every where , Brachtmann . I want to shake hands and tell you how glad I am to be under your orders again .

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: We wo n't talk of being under my orders , my dear Voelkerlingk . You know how badly we need you , and how anxious we are to have you take the lead in the coming debate .Richard bows .I suppose we may count on your speaking on the Divorce Bill next Friday ? RichardhesitatingWhy — I had hardly expected ——

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: It 's the very thing we want of you . According to the Socialists , a man and his wife are no more bound to each other than a pair of cuckoos . We need a speaker of your eloquence and your convictions to proclaim the sanctity of the marriage-bond .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: But I hardly know if I should have time to get my facts together . And besides —He draws Brachtmann aside and continues in a low tone .An hour or two ago I received a copy of a speech that a fellow called Meixner has been making against me . The man is a former secretary of mine , turned Socialist ——

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: Ah — Meixner was your secretary ?

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: You knew of this ?

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: My dear Voelkerlingk , do n't you see that after such an attack it 's doubly important that you should speak on this very question ? As for the party , I think I may say in its name that our asking you to do so is equivalent to a vote of confidence .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Thanks , Brachtmann . I believe you 're right . My refusal might be misinterpreted . Brachtmannturning toward the othersWe were speaking of this when you joined us . We have all received copies of the paper . Richardto the groupThen I must apologise for not having mentioned the matter ; but I was waiting to bring it before you in committee . It seems to be a question of personal spite , for my son has received the paper too .

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: And Madame von Voelkerlingk ?

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: My wife ? Why do you ask ?

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: Look at this .Leads Richard to the writing-table and points to the paper . Richard starts , but controls himself instantly .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: We were just wondering how we could get rid of the thing before it is discovered , and we had reluctantly decided that none of us is sufficiently intimate here to tamper with the Countess 's papers . Now , if you , my dear Baron — as an old friend of the family — knowing how important it is to spare her any excitement —— Richardlooking at him sharplyThere is only one person entitled to remove that paper , and that is Count Kellinghausen . I will speak to him at once . PrinceasideIrreproachable !

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: My dear Voelkerlingk , for heaven 's sake leave Kellinghausen out of the question !

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: How can I ?

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: I have been in politics long enough to take such incidents philosophically . But Kellinghausen , easy-going as he is , strikes me as the kind of man who might make an ass of himself in such an emergency . If he loses his head he may do the party an incalculable amount of harm ; whereas , if we can keep this thing from him , it will blow over in a week , and nobody be any the worse for it .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: But you forget that I am as much involved in this as Kellinghausen . It is impossible that I should stand aside and allow any reflection to be cast on — er ——

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: You are quite right . But wait a moment . You said you meant to bring the matter up in committee , which is undoubtedly the proper way of dealing with it . The committee meets the day after to-morrow ; and all I ask is that you should say nothing till then .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: And suppose I agree to that what becomes of this paper ?Pointing to the writing-table .What if the Countess finds it ?

sp.speaker: von Berkelwitz
sp.p: Gentlemen , I 'm only a plain country squire , and I have n't your refinements of conscience .He takes the paper , tears it up and throws it into the wastepaper basket . Brachtmann and the Prince laugh .

sp.speaker: von Berkelwitz
sp.p: After which act of felony I suppose I had better make my escape .Shakes hands with the others and goes out .

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: Then it 's understood that , in the interests of the party , you will ——

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: ‘ Sh . Here is our host .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen enters
sp.p: Kellinghausen . Ah , there you are , Richard ! My dear fellow , I 've been hunting for you high and low . I was actually reduced to asking Madame von Voelkerlingk where you were . “ My dear Count , ” she said , “ it 's fifteen years since I 've known where my husband was . ” Nice reputation you 've got ! Well , now I 've run you to earth , sit down and let 's have a talk .To the others .I have n't had a chance to say two words to him yet .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: My dear Brachtmann , shall we ——?

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: No , no ; do n't run off . Richard and I have no secrets . Let us take possession of this quiet corner .To Conrad , who is passing with a tray of refreshments .Conrad , what have you got there ? Lion brew from the wood , eh ?

sp.speaker: Conrad
sp.p: Yes , your Excellency .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: That 's what we always had at Bismarck 's . H 'm — in those days there was a power in the land . It weighed on us rather heavily at times , but we were none the worse for it . Your health , Richard , my dear fellow ! Gentlemen , your healths ! How deuced quiet you all are ! You look as if I 'd invited you to my own funeral . Good Lord , if you knew how glad I am to have got the Reichstag off my shoulders !— The other day , down at the polls , I said to one of our Lengenfeld peasants : “ My dear friend — ”they 're all our dear friends at election-time ; we even have to put up with being their dear friends“ My dear friend , ” said I , “ I hope you 're going to vote for my successor ? ” — “ What will he give me for it ? ” says he . “ What will the Socialist give you ? ” said I . “ The Socialist will call you all names , and I like to hear you called names . It makes me laugh , ” the fellow answered . And he was right . We must amuse the masses and they 'll love us . Circus-riding , my dear friends that 's all the nobility are good for !

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: We shall miss your cheerful view of life , my dear Kellinghausen .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: H 'm — that 's about the only epitaph I can hope for . Ha ! ha !— Well — I say , Richard , what sort of a fellow is that Meixner ?The others look up quickly .Was n't he your secretary at one time ?

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: How long ago ?

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: It must be ten or twelve years .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: Well , he has certainly profited by the training you gave him . He 's raving against you like a madman .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Did you happen to run across him ?

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: Heaven forbid !

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Did you hear what he said ?

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: Yes ; Holtzmann told me about him . And I 've had a lot of his speeches and proclamations sent to me . Capital stuff for lighting the fire . Well , thank the Lord , it 's all over .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: I wish I knew how to thank you , Michael ——

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: Nonsense . None of that . By the way , I picked up a pamphlet in the train to-day — “ The Ordeal ” or some such name . Holtzmann tells me that Norbert wrote it . Is that true ?Richard nods .

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: Ah , indeed — your son wrote ——?

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: I say , Richard , you give him a long rein , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: My dear Michael , the chief thing I have to thank my father for is that he gave me one . I vowed long ago that Norbert should have as much freedom as I had .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: Well , we shall have to take the young scamp in hand before long .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: I wish you would . I should like to know who has put him up to this . He wo n't tell me .

div.stage: Enter Beata , with Baron Ludwig von Voelkerlingk .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: May we join you ? Do n't let us break up your party .

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: Advancing toward the other men .Will you allow me ? Beatato Michael , in a low toneWell , are you enjoying yourself ?

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: Immensely , dear , immensely .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Did you like the way I arranged the seats at table ?

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: Could n't have been better . The brothers not too close together , yet near enough to talk . Now you must follow it up , and get them to make friends — eh ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: That is what I 've come for .To Richard .My dear Voelkerlingk , I want to speak to you .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: To Richard , as he approaches .Mind you obey orders , now !Joins the others .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: I am glad you are not too tired , Beata .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: I 've been growing stronger every day since the elections . But you must take some notice of Leonie , Richard . She is saying things .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Let her . It 's her specialty .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Every one knows that she never comes here , and her being here to-night is making people talk .

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: Approaching his brother , evidently at Kellinghausen 's instigation .Ah , here are the two friends talking together .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Looking from one brother to the other .And the two enemies , too — thank heaven !

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: The Countess is right , Richard . It was foolish of us not to speak to each other .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: My dear Ludwig , perhaps we had n't enough to say .

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: Or too much !

lg.l: No , no . I am going to leave you two together .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Why do you look at her so strangely ?

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: Strangely ? What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: You begrudge me this friendship , Ludwig .

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: Do I ? Perhaps . You must remember that I am very lonely . I had hoped that your house might ——

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: My house ? With Leonie ——?

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: Yes — your friend is different from Leonie .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: You need n't envy me , Ludwig . My friend is a dying woman . Every day I ask myself if I shall ever see her again .

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: My dear Richard , the woman lives in a thousand energies . She will survive us both .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: God grant it !

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: But — be on your guard .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: What do you mean ?

lg.l: Can we find a quiet corner somewhere ?
lg.stage: He takes Richard 's arm and they go toward the other room .
lg.l: What a touching spectacle ! Look , Norbert !

sp.speaker: Baron Ludwig
sp.p: Do n't detain us , Leonie . We 're going to have our photograph taken .He and Richard go out .Leonieadvancing toward the frontHow enchanting ! And Beata as the angel of peace ! Quite a new role for you , is n't it , dear ? But you 're so versatile !

lg.l: Dear Leonie , find fault with me when I sow discord , but praise me when

sp.speaker: Leonie
sp.p: Do you care so much for praise ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Do n't you ?

sp.speaker: Leonie
sp.p: Oh , no one ever praises me . I suppose I do n't know how to play my cards . Norbert , please have the carriage called .

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: Very well , mother .Goes out .

sp.speaker: Leonie
sp.p: Ah , Prince — good-evening !He kisses her hand .How is it we never see you at our missionary meetings ? Her Royal Highness wished me to say that she counts on your help . Is n't that flattering ?To the others .The Prince is one of us , you know . He serves the cause of religion faithfully ——

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: And in poverty of spirit . That 's my special merit , you know , Baroness . Brachtmannaside to the Prince

sp.speaker: You reprobate !
sp.p: Leonie . But pray do n't let me disturb you , for I must really be off . My carriage is waiting , and my coachman is so cross . We 're all the slaves of our carriages .To Kellinghausen .It has been so delightful — dear Beata is such a wonderful hostess . Our great stateswoman knows so well how to keep her party in hand . Willingly or unwillingly , she makes them all come into line ; do n't you , Beata , dear ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: I 'm afraid you are among the unwilling to-night , Leonie .

sp.speaker: Leonie
sp.p: Oh , I 'm not as adaptable as some of your friends . Brachtmannaside to the PrinceDo you hear those amenities ? Princeto BrachtmannThe Baroness is dispensing Christian charity sprinkled with arsenic . Let 's efface ourselves .They move quietly into the background .

sp.speaker: Leonie
sp.p: To Kellinghausen , with whom she has been talking .No , no , my dear Count you must n't think of it . Norbert will put me in my carriage . And meanwhile , I want to have a little chat with dear Beata . We always have so many things to say to each other . Kellinghausenkissing her handAt your orders , my dear friend . I 'll draw the curtain to protect your tete-a-tete .He draws the curtain between the columns and goes out .

sp.speaker: Leonie
sp.p: How wonderfully well you look to-night , Beata ! Not in the least like a prospective grandmother .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Why , as to that , Leonie , it looks as though you and I were to be made grandmothers on the same day .

sp.speaker: Leonie
sp.p: Ah , really ? Well , Ellen is a delightful child . Where is she , by the way ? You do n't seem to care to let her be seen in your neighbourhood on such occasions .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Seen ? In my neighbourhood ? You have an odd way of putting things . But I believe you had something to say to me .

sp.speaker: Leonie
sp.p: I know I ought n't to keep you from your other guests , but it 's such a pleasure to have you to myself . I wonder what has become of Norbert ?— I must say , Beata , I can n't help admiring your self-possession . I do n't see how you can be so unconcerned .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: What should I be concerned about ?

sp.speaker: Leonie
sp.p: Why , you do n't mean —? I should almost think you — But I do n't know how to express myself . It 's so very painful .— There are such dreadful people in the world .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Are there ?

sp.speaker: Leonie
sp.p: This former secretary of Richard 's , for instance , who has made such a shocking speech against him . You 've received a copy , of course ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Not that I know of . Leoniedrawing a paper from her pocketAh — I brought mine with me . Perhaps it might interest you .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Not in the least , my dear .

sp.speaker: Leonie
sp.p: You are mentioned in it , too . Beatasmiling

sp.speaker: Really ?
sp.p: Leonie . Only between the lines , of course .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Between the lines ? What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: Leonie
sp.p: This is the paragraph ; the one marked with a blue pencil . Do n't be horrified . It will make you laugh , of course . I laughed over it myself .Beata takes the paper , looking firmly at Leonie as she does so . She reads the paper , throws it aside , and looks at Leonie again , without speaking .Good heavens , how pale you are ! I did n't realise — Shall I get you a glass of water ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: No , thanks .Controlling herself with an effort .Does Richard know of this ?

sp.speaker: Leonie
sp.p: Oh , yes . Does n't Michael ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Certainly not .— He would have — Will you let me have this paper ?

sp.speaker: Leonie
sp.p: To show Michael ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Naturally . In a matter involving his honour ——

sp.speaker: Leonie
sp.p: You do n't mean to make a scandal ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: What do you call a scandal ? Have n't you made one in bringing me this ?

sp.speaker: Leonie
sp.p: I mean that your husband might ——

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: My husband will do as he sees fit .

sp.speaker: Leonie
sp.p: You are very sure of yourself .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: My dear Leonie , remember that you are in my house .

sp.speaker: Leonie
sp.p: My dear Beata , we are always in each other 's houses ; we can n't meet at the street corners , like servants .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: You are right . Say what you were going to say .

sp.speaker: Leonie
sp.p: Oh , I have held my tongue so long !

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Why have you , if you had anything to say ?

sp.speaker: Leonie
sp.p: Listen , Beata . I am not going to discuss the relations between my husband and yourself . It 's a subject that no longer interests me . But it was you who took him away from me , and when I found you had taken him , I turned to my boy instead . Then you took him too . Now I have nothing left — nothing but my position in society , which I have built up slowly , year by year , by my own efforts , as you know . I am in the Princess Agnes 's most intimate set , I am patroness of — but all this does n't interest you . But how have I accomplished it ? Simply by keeping my eyes shut and appearing to sanction your friendship with Richard .— And now , if you persist in dragging your husband in , there will be a scandal , and I shall have to sue for a divorce ; and that will be excessively unpleasant for us all . Do n't you agree with me ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: I might say so many things in reply .— In the first place , whatever I have taken was never really yours .— But no matter . I will only ask you one thing : have you thought of Ellen and Norbert ?

sp.speaker: Leonie
sp.p: Oh , Ellen and Norbert ! I 've no objection to the match , none whatever — but it 's your scheme , not mine , and you can n't expect me to be particularly enthusiastic about it . But I should think it would be one more reason for you to keep quiet .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Then — if you do n't mean to do anything — why did you bring me this ? Leoniewith irrepressible triumphWhy did I bring it ? Because I —relapses into her usual amiability— I thought it might interest you , and you see I was not mistaken . Ah , here comes Norbert !

lg.l: I 'm sorry to have kept you , mother . The carriage was —
Why , Aunt Beata , what 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: Leonie
sp.p: Well , good-bye , Beata . Do be careful of yourself ! I should be so sorry to think I had done anything to excite you . Come , Norbert , you must put me in the carriage , and then you can come back to your dear aunt .

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: I beg your pardon , mother , but I think Aunt Beata needs me now . If you 'll wait for me a moment downstairs ——

sp.speaker: Leonie
sp.p: What did I say ? I congratulate you , Beata !She goes out alone .

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: What has she been saying to you ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Oh , she was right — so right ! Norbertalarmed

sp.speaker: Aunt Beata !
sp.p: Beatawith an effortNorbert — my son — take me to Ellen . In a few minutes I shall be quite ——

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: Come , come —Leads her gently out . Sounds of talk and laughter come from the inner room .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: Putting his head through the curtains .Ha ! No one there ? Have our wives made way with each other ?To Richard , who has followed him .They 're not so deuced fond of one another . I say , old man , just now , when I was talking about the elections , why did you all put on that air of statesmanlike reserve ? Did I say anything out of the way ?

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: What an absurd idea !

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: One is always liable to make an ass of one 's self . I 'm not conscious of having blundered , but — oh , well , I sha'n ' t get anything out of you .Raising the curtain and calling out —Brachtmann — Usingen — come here a moment .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Michael , if you take my advice we 'll drop the election for the present . I give you my word that if anything occurs that reflects on you ——

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: On me ? Reflects on me ? What on earth do you mean ? I 'm thinking of the party . Our business is to look out for the party .

div.stage: Enter Brachtmann and the Prince , followed a moment or two later by Norbert .

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: Hear , hear ! But what are you talking about ? Kellinghausento NorbertAha , young man , where have you come from ? Tea in the school-room , eh ?

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: Aunt Beata was not very well , Uncle Michael .Richard starts .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: Ah ?

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: She is feeling better now . She will be here in a few minutes .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: That 's good — that 's good . By the way , Master Norbert , we 're going to put you through your paces . How about this so-called “ Ordeal , ” eh ? Do you own up to it ?

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: I 'm proud to , Uncle . At least , no — not so very proud ; for I 've found out lately that it 's all been said before , a thousand times better than I 've said it .

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: And also by a member of the Conservative party ?

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: Well — no — not exactly .

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: Ah — but that 's the point .

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: I beg your pardon , Herr von Brachtmann , I thought truth was truth , no matter who uttered it .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: What is truth ? said Pilate .

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: And washed his hands . We also wash our hands of many things , your Highness . I have even heard it said that the use of soap and water is the only thing that distinguishes us from the masses . But no matter how much washing we do , we can n't wash off the blood we have shed in the abuse of our class-privileges . Princeto RichardVery neatly parried . He has a good wrist .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: My dear Norbert , will you give your venerable parent a hearing ? We have left far behind us many of what you call our “ class-privileges ” ; but their traditional spirit still survives . And that spirit , whether the modern world condemns it , or the middle-classes make it ridiculous by aping it — that spirit is the safeguard of our order . Believe me , Norbert , we must stand or fall by it .

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: Then we must fall , father .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Possibly — even probably . But meanwhile the one distinction we have left is the right to dispose of our lives . When a nobleman of the Italian Renaissance , or a young blade of the court of Louis XIII ., crossed the threshold of his house , he was never sure of re-entering it alive . That was what gave him his audacity , his splendid indifference to danger . Today we no longer stake our lives so lightly ; but the fact that they are ours to stake still gives its keenest edge to living .

sp.speaker: The Others
sp.p: Hear ! Hear !

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: My dear father , you have given us an admirable explanation of the personal view of death . But life is not a personal matter at all . You have said so often enough . Our lives belong to the ideals for which we fight , they belong to the state or to the race ——

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: And how about our personal sense of honour ? What of that , Norbert ? Are we to be forbidden to defend with our lives the few things we hold sacred on earth ? May we no longer fall upon the scoundrel who assails them ? You will hardly convince us of that , Norbert .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Then again , Norbert , there may be cases — you are too young to have foreseen them , but they exist — where an honourable man may have done irreparable injury to another 's honour . If he admits his guilt , and satisfaction is demanded of him , what is he to do ? Is he to run away , or to shelter himself behind the law ? The law , which was made to protect the honour of serfs ! Should you expect that of him , Norbert ?

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: If your man of honour admits his guilt , and is ready to pay the penalty , let him be his own judge .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: H 'm ——

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: But I beg your pardon , father ; that is hardly the point . It was all very well for the aristocracy to make its own laws when it had the power to enforce them ; but what is to become of its precious “ class-privileges ” when the modern world laughs at them and the mob refuses to recognise them ? When that day comes , I do n't see what we can do but take shelter behind the law .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: I do n't understand you , Norbert . Give us an instance .

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: Nothing easier , Uncle Michael . What do you propose to do with the scoundrel who has been insulting you in his electioneering speeches ?There is a startled movement among his listeners .You do n't mean to challenge him , I suppose ?

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: What do you ——?

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: Unless you treat the whole matter with silent contempt and I fancy you 'll hardly do that it seems to me that a libel suit is the only alternative .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: Norbert — are you dreaming — or ——

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: Why — Uncle Michael — did n't you know ?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Now you 've done it , young man !

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: Do any of you know what he 's driving at ?

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: Richard , what does this mean ? What is going on behind my back ? You call yourself my friend — why have you kept me in the dark ? Richardvery quietlyIn the first place , dear Michael , we only heard of the business an hour or two ago ; in the second placeas he speaks , Beata enters from behind, I am mixed up in it myself .

lg.l: You ? In a slander that concerns me ?
Then there was all the more reason ——

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: My dear Kellinghausen , the fault is mine . For the sake of the party , I asked Voelkerlingk not to — Princesuddenly noticing BeataH 'm . Perhaps we had better —he advances toward BeataMy dear Countess —— Beata enters quietly .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Do n't be afraid . I know what you are speaking of . I know all about it . Michael , if these gentlemen would allow us to talk the matter over by ourselves ——

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: Thank you , my dear . But I think you had better keep out of it . Richard — Brachtmann — if you 'll come to my study ——They both assent .Richardapproaching BeataI will say good-night , Countess .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Good-night , my dear Voelkerlingk .Rapidly , in a low voice , as he bends above her hand .Does he know ? Richardin the same tone

sp.speaker: Not yet
sp.p: Beataaloud , with conventional cordialityI shall see you to-morrow ?Richard bows , and follows the other men toward the door .

div.head: ACT III

lg.l: The same scene : in the afternoon . Holtzmann is waiting . Enter
Kellinghausen in hat and fur-lined coat .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: Ah , Holtzmann — this is very good of you . I 'm extremely obliged to you for coming .Shakes hands with him .Sorry to have kept you waiting .Takes off his hat and coat .Sit down — sit down .— That is ,— perhaps we 'd better — Oh , well , my wife 's not likely to come in just now .— A cigarette ?

sp.speaker: Holtzmann
sp.p: Thanks . I do n't smoke . Kellinghausenlighting a cigaretteYou remember Meixner the fellow who gave us such a lot of trouble during the elections ? I believe you and he have crossed swords once or twice in public ; and did n't you tell me that you knew him personally ? When was it that you ran across him ?

sp.speaker: Holtzmann
sp.p: There was only one inn in the village , and his room and mine were on the same landing . The meeting was over at eleven , and I went to bed soon after . About midnight in walks Meixner , as cool as you please , and sits down on my bed . “ We have n't finished that argument yet . Let 's have it out now , ” he said . And there he sat till six in the morning .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: Takes a copy of the “ Lengenfeld News ” out of his pocket and glances at it .Did that happen before or after the twelfth of January ?

sp.speaker: Holtzmann
sp.p: It happened before he made that speech . KellinghausenstartledWhat ? You knew ——?

sp.speaker: Holtzmann
sp.p: Why — naturally .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: Herr Holtzmann , we were in the train together for hours . We drove together for miles . I have always treated you as a friend . Why did you never speak of this ?Holtzmann remains silent .Let me tell you one thing : you can n't put me off with a shrug . If you think you can , you do n't know me .

sp.speaker: Holtzmann
sp.p: I beg your pardon , Count Kellinghausen — but I must remind you that I am not in your service .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: My dear Herr Holtzmann , you are known as one of the most zealous supporters of our party . Probably you attach some importance to that fact . Your silence in this matter surprises me , and I shall not fail to draw my own conclusions . HoltzmannrisingYou must draw what conclusions you please , sir . Personally I have nothing to gain by serving your party . I might have a living at any moment , and if I have preferred , for the present , to devote myself to politics , it was only because I thought I could be of use to the cause . Kellinghausenafter a pauseI have offended you . You must make allowances for my excitement — this business has unnerved me .Holds out his hand .Sit down again and let me ask you a question . Has this Meixner any recognised standing in his party , or is he merely a hanger-on ?

sp.speaker: Holtzmann
sp.p: He must have a certain standing , since he is their candidate for the next election .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: Ha ! ha ! A nice lot they are ! Well , the gentleman has given us his measure by sending copies of this paper to the wives of the men he attacks .

sp.speaker: Holtzmann
sp.p: If he has done that , sir , can you guess his reasons ?

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: No . Can you ?

sp.speaker: Holtzmann
sp.p: Perhaps ——

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: Well ——?

sp.speaker: Holtzmann
sp.p: I 'm sorry , sir — but I can n't say anything more just now . KellinghausenrisingGood-day , then , Herr Holtzmann .

lg.l: Hounds ! Brigands ! Damn them ! All tarred with the same brush ——

sp.speaker: Beata enters
sp.p: BeataquietlyFlying into a passion wo n't mend matters , Michael .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: And I can n't make you out , either . Here they are , throwing mud at us — calling you I wo n't say what — and you stand there like — like — Have n't you got any blood in your veins ? Do n't you realise what it all means ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: I have n't much strength to spare , and I have to economise my emotions .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: Good God — how white you are ! Do n't mind me — I 'll pull myself together . We wo n't talk of the damned thing any more .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: It will be the first time in twenty years that we have n't talked over what you had on your mind .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: I wish to heaven I 'd never told you of it . The devil take Leonie ! She can n't hold her cursed meddling tongue ; Richard ought to muzzle her . By the way , it 's strange he has n't shown himself to-day .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: I have had a note from him . He asked me to tell you that he is deep in his speech . He is coming as soon as he has a moment to spare .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: There you are again ! Just when the man needs a clear head for the great work that 's before him , he finds himself involved in this filthy — Ah , well , I 'll have the dogs by the throat yet ! I 'll have them howling for mercy !

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Do calm yourself , Michael . Look — your face is all on fire . You know it 's bad for you to excite yourself .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: There , there — I 'm quiet again . Do n't I always do what you tell me ? Ah , if I had n't had you all these years , the Lord knows what would have become of me !

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Then , on the whole , I 've been — satisfactory ? KellinghausenlaughingThat sounds as if you were asking for a reference .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Perhaps I am . I want to have one to show in case of need .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: And when do you expect to need it ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Who knows ? Enter Conrad . Conradannouncing

sp.speaker: Baron Brachtmann
sp.p: Kellinghausento BeataDo you wish to see him ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: Bows to Kellinghausen and kisses Beata 's hand .I am sorry we were not on our guard yesterday , Countess . Even if you had to know of this stupid business , you need n't have heard of it till it had blown over .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Do n't reproach yourself , Baron . I should have been sorry to miss such a chance of enlarging my knowledge of human nature .

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: Well , at all events , I beg of you both not to take it too seriously . And as for you , my dear Kellinghausen , I say again as I 've said before : for God 's sake , keep out of the courts .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: Ah ——?

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: Why , my dear man , have n't I been accused of arson and forgery ? Have n't I been charged with bribing my constituents to perjure themselves — not to speak of my dodging my taxes , and other sleight-of-hand performances ? That 's merely the political way of poking fun .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: H 'm — your digestion must be stronger than mine . But those charges concerned no one but yourself ; if I stood alone in this business , I might see the humour of it . But let them beware how they attack my family ! Besides , I 've taken steps already ——

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: What have you done ?

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: I got hold of my counsel this morning . He has made out a retraction which the scoundrel is to sign . If he wo n't sign it , we 'll take other means . He is to be at my lawyer 's at three o'clock . Beatastarting up

sp.speaker: What ? To-day ?
sp.p: Kellinghausen . To-day . The sooner the better . By the way , what time is it ? I must be on hand myself . Brachtmann , will you come with me ?

sp.speaker: Brachtmann
sp.p: I was going to propose it .While Kellinghausen puts on his coat , he turns to Beata .If you have any influence over him , for heaven 's sake —— Beatain a low voiceI can do nothing .

sp.speaker: Kellinghausen
sp.p: Well , dear , good-bye . If Richard turns up , be sure you make him wait . I shall be back in an hour .Kellinghausen and Brachtmann go out .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Closing her eyes , with a miserable smile .In an hour ! Enter Ellen . Ellenin the doorway

sp.speaker: Mother !
sp.p: Beata . Come in , dear child . Ellenkneeling down beside herMother , mother dear , what has happened ? What is it ? Papa is so excited and talks to himself so strangely — and you — oh , mother ! BeatasmilingWell what have I done ?

sp.speaker: Ellen
sp.p: If I tell you , you wo n't — wo n't stay away ? You 'll come and lean over my bed every night — just as you 've always done ? BeatasurprisedThen you 're awake — when I come ?

sp.speaker: Ellen
sp.p: Always , always . I never go to sleep till I 've heard you .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Dearest ! And yet you never stirred !

sp.speaker: Ellen
sp.p: Oh , I prided myself on that ! But last night it was so hard to keep quiet . I could feel your tears on my face — oh , how you were crying ! And I did so want to cry with you . But I held my breath and lay as still as I could .— Mother , what has happened ? Wo n't you tell me ? I 'm not a child any longer .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Listen , dear . I want to ask you a question . Is there any one in the world — besides your father and me — that you 're very fond of ? EllensoftlyYou know , mother . I do n't have to tell you things ——

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Some one you 're so fond of that you could live for him — or even die for him ?

sp.speaker: Ellen
sp.p: There 's nothing in the world I would n't do for him !

lg.stage: Softly stroking her hair and cheeks .

sp.speaker: Dr. Kahlenberg
sp.p: Beatato EllenGo , dear . That is all I wanted to know .

sp.speaker: Ellen
sp.p: Mother !Goes out .

div.stage: Enter Dr. Kahlenberg . Conrad goes out .

sp.speaker: Dr. Kahlenberg
sp.p: You sent for me , Countess ? Nothing wrong , I hope ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Why , this is your hour for consultations , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: Dr. Kahlenberg
sp.p: Oh , there was no one there but two or three whining women . The kind that can be cured by the atmosphere of a fashionable doctor 's waiting-room ; so I 'm letting them wait .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Listening , as though to make sure that they are alone .I sha'n ' t keep you long . Doctor you know how often I have said to you : “ My dear friend , I 've got to live — I 've simply got to live ; show me how — ” and how you 've always answered : “ The only way is to avoid excitement . ” Well — I 've borne that in mind — I 've schooled myself to look at life through a tombstone , as it were — my own tombstone , doctor ! I 've done that . But now — now there are storms ahead , perhaps disasters . If they come , my judgment and energy are equal to them — but my valves are not . I found that out last night — it was only those drops of yours that saved me . But I can n't live on those drops — you 've warned me not to take them too often . And I do n't want to die of this . Doctor , you must help me !

sp.speaker: Dr. Kahlenberg
sp.p: Why , what 's the meaning of all this ? H 'm . You 're right . Strophanthus and digitalis are not meant for human nature 's daily food . Besides , the effect might wear off .— My dear Countess , take your courage in both hands and run away . Turn your back on all these emotions . Human life is simply a process of molecular adjustment complicated by moral idiosyncrasies . BeatalaughingI 'm so glad to know it , doctor .Growing serious .But there is no time to run away . The storm may break in an hour .

sp.speaker: Dr. Kahlenberg
sp.p: Child , what has happened ? Ah , well , I never ask questions .— In an hour ?— I am going home to despatch my whining women , and then I 'll drop in again and see what has happened in the interval .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: And if to-day is only the prelude ?

sp.speaker: Dr. Kahlenberg
sp.p: So much the better . Then we shall have time to look the thing in the face . Meanwhile I 'll give you something new to take — something that your system has n't got used to . We physicians have a supply of such remedies to tide us over bad places .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Thank you .

sp.speaker: Dr. Kahlenberg
sp.p: Give me both hands , Countess . You and I know death too well to be much afraid of it . But if you want to live I 'll do my best to help you . And now I 'll go and assure my other patients that they 're really ill. Good-bye .He goes out . In the hall he is heard greeting Norbert .

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: Aunt Beata , I 'm so glad to see you looking so well . I was almost afraid ——

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: It always cheers me to see you , Norbert . And to-day especially ——

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: To-day ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: ‘ Sh — to-day is a lucky day .

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: Lucky ? In what way ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Wait and see ! Wait and see !

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: I say , Aunt Beata , you 're not making fun of me ? I do n't half like the way you 're smiling to yourself .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Well , you must make the best of it , dear boy !

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: Aunt Beata — you 're not the same since yesterday . I knew it all along . What a beastly business life is ! You — you — of all women !— that they should dare attack you ! The scoundrels — the miserable sneaking scoundrels !

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Norbert , dear , you must see that this is a matter we can n't discuss . Besides , I have something else to talk to you about . Can you tell me what time it is ?

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: Half-past four .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Will you ring for the lamps , please ? Ring twice .Norbert rings .I have only a few minutes to spare , but it wo n't take long to —Conrad brings in two lamps , and draws the curtainsto tell you what I —She hesitates , constrained by Conrad 's presence .This is Miss Mansborough 's afternoon . She has probably gone out .Conrad leaves the room .You will find Ellen alone in her sitting-room — go and look for her — and when you find her , put your arms about her , and say to her , “ I love you , and I shall always love you , in this world and the next ” — provided there is any next !

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: Aunt Beata !Falls on his knees before her and hides his face in her lap .Beatastruggling with her tearsAnd then sit down in the twilight , you and Ellen , quietly , side by side , and talk of all the happiness that is coming to you and of all the good you mean to do . Let it be your hour of consecration . And I shall be with you all the while — feeling your happiness , thinking your thoughts — all through this next hour of my life .— Now go , Norbert . I hear some one coming — it must be your father . I will tell him — go , dear , go .

sp.speaker: Norbert
sp.p: Aunt Beata !Kisses her hand .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Your hour of consecration remember that , Norbert .Norbert goes out .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: What has happened ? You look radiant .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Taking his hand and holding it fast .I have settled the future of our children . No matter what happens to us — Why , Richard , are n't you the least bit pleased ?— Oh , how ill you look !

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: What sort of a night did you have , Beata ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Not so bad .— And how goes the speech ? Are you in sight of land ?

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Beata — I do n't know if I shall be able to speak to-morrow . BeataalarmedBut you must . You must . They all count on you . Dear , you must . Is it because of that wretched business last night ?

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Partly , I suppose . This new danger has stirred up the whole past .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: And your conscience is bothering you again ?

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: You call it conscience , Beata ; I call it consistency . How dare I speak on this bill , how dare I take such a stand before God and man , when my whole life gives me the lie ?— Good God !— To stand up and talk about the sanctity of marriage — about the family life as the main support of society — to parade such an argument before the cynics of the Opposition , when with my own hands I have helped to tear down that very support — no , no , I can n't justify myself without adopting their own cynical and materialistic creed . And not even then ; for what I call God they call social expediency ; and this new idol of theirs is more exacting than the Jehovah of the old dispensation . As to acknowledging that words are one thing and actions another — that the man in me is not accountable to the statesman — well , I have n't sunk as low as that — what I give I must give without an afterthought .— And so all my ideas crumble into dust , all my reasoning ends in contradiction — and I find myself powerless to plead the very cause I have at heart !

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: But why , dearest , why ?

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Forgive me . I am so tired ; my mind is a blank . First that dreadful scene last night , when a moment 's hesitation would have ruined us both . Then my long night at my desk — the superhuman effort of collecting my thoughts after all I 'd been through . But as I worked , my subject took such hold of me that I 've only just waked up to the question — how on earth is it all to end ?Beata is silent .Oh , Beata , the truth , the truth ! Oh , to be at one with one 's self ! To have the right to stand up openly for one 's convictions ! I would give everything for it — happiness , life itself , everything !

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: And yet you love life .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: I ? No — not now . Now that our falsehood is closing in on us , death would be — but do n't be frightened ; I shall do nothing foolish . There are two of us , and we must hold together . I am so used to sharing every thought with you .— What has happened since yesterday ? I suppose Michael has given up the absurd idea of prosecuting the man .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: On the contrary .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: At this moment he has probably found out whatever your former secretary knows about us .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: What on earth do you mean ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: I have n't interrupted you , dear , because speaking seemed to clear your thoughts . But I have n't attempted to answer you , because every minute is precious .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Has n't Brachtmann been here ?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Brachtmann came too late .

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Then ——?

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Even if he had come sooner he could not have prevented anything . Dearest , Michael may come back at any moment , and when he comes we must be ready ——

sp.speaker: Richard
sp.p: Do n't go on , Beata . Let us suppose the worst : say that Meixner has unearthed a few suspicious circumstances — what use can he make of them ? He can n't produce any proofs .

sp.speaker: Beata
sp.p: Who knows ?

sp.speaker: Richard
